content:
Young Palinyang’
 Gaspah Emukuru Juma
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long time ago there lived an orphan boy 
 caled Palinyang’. 
 
 Palinyang’s parents were kiled by 
 robers when he was only six months 
 old. 
 
 
 As the vilagers mourned the death of 
 
 Palinyang’s parents, they wondered what 
 would become of Palinyang’. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After the burial, Sausau, the vilage
 
 headman caled a meting. 
 
 
 Sausau was respected and feared at the
 same time because of the way he 
 dresed and talked. His hair was long
 
 and fel on his back. 
 
 
 It was believed that Sausau lived in the
 forest long before tres were cut down
 and houses were built. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 During the meting, Lokeyokoni, a very 
 rich vilager, adopted Palinyang’. 
 
 
 Lokeyokoni had many sons and 
 daughters. The daughters helped their 
 mother with household chores while the 
 
 sons went out to graze their father’s big 
 herd of catle. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Palinyang’ grew up in this family and was
 very hapy. 
 
 He was loved and he loved everybody.
 
 He enjoyed grazing the animals in the
 
 fields. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Palinyang’ loved one particular cow so 
 much that he gave it the name Alinyang’. 
 
 
 Alinyang’ was the oldest cow in the 
 whole herd. For this reason, the owner 
 
 valued it a lot. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day when the boys were out grazing
 
 the animals, it started raining and they
 had to shelter under a tre. 
 
 
 The rain fel for many hours until it was
 dark. 
 When it eventualy stoped raining, the
 
 boys went to colect the animals and
 take them home but there were no
 
 animals to be sen. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They were afraid of what their father 
 would do to them if they arived home 
 
 without the animals. 
 
 When they could not trace the catle, two 
 
 boys decided to go to their uncle’s home 
 while two others went to their aunt’s 
 place. 
 
 
 Palinyang’ decided to continue loking 
 
 for the animals til he found them. He 
 had no uncle or aunt to run to. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Palinyang’ folowed al the tracks that he
 knew while singing the name of his
 
 favourite cow. 
 This is how the song went: 
 
 
 Pi pi Alinyang’! 
 Pi pi Alinyang’! 
 
 Chaka akula chi! 
 Chaka orete chi! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Palinyang’ went on singing the song 
 throughout the night. 
 
 He steped on the cow dung but it was 
 cold. 
 He then steped on the urine but it was 
 
 cold as wel. Palinyang’ did not give up. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At dawn, Palinyang’ reached a smal
 vilage and found the animals in the care
 of the vilage headman. He pleaded with
 
 the headman to let him lead the animals
 home, but the headman refused. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Frustrated, Palinyang’ started singing his 
 song as he turned to go home. 
 
 It was then that Alinyang’, the oldest cow, 
 heard Palinyang’. 
 Alinyang raised her ears and started 
 
 folowing Palinyang’. 
 Al the animals broke from the enclosure 
 
 and folowed Palinyang. He lead them 
 home. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When they reached home, vilagers were waiting because
 they had heard Palinyang’s voice from far. They al sang
 songs praising Palinyang’. 
 
 
 Lokeyokoni thanked Palinyang’ and bought him a red bag for
 carying boks to schol. 
 
 
 And that is how Palinyang’ started going to schol.
